sections.text: Arjun Mehta: Hi Colton—Arjun Mehta here. Thanks for taking a few minutes. I’ll be brief: I work with teams that are trying to get sharper on “who is our best customer?” and then translate that into clearer targeting and messaging. Is now still okay?
Colton Medina: Yep, I’ve got about five minutes. What are you seeing with companies like ours?

Arjun Mehta: Perfect. So the product is Customer_Analyzer. It pulls in the customer signals you already have—CRM fields, onboarding survey answers, product usage events, even support tickets or interview notes—and produces two things: a fit score by account/segment, and positioning recommendations that explain how to win more deals with the right narrative.  
Before I go too far—at Zephyrroot Materials, where do you feel the biggest pain right now: picking the right segments to prioritize, or getting product and go-to-market aligned on what to build and why?
Colton Medina: Honestly both, but if I had to pick: prioritization. We’re debating which types of customers are really worth focusing on.

Arjun Mehta: That’s exactly where we start. One feature I think you’d care about is our fit estimation. You define fit drivers that matter to your business—things like industry, company size, problem severity, time-to-value, adoption patterns, and even support burden and churn-risk signals—and we compute a fit score from 0 to 100 at both the account and segment level.  
The part customers like is it’s not a black box: you get a driver breakdown showing why a segment scores high or low, plus segment comparisons—like “SMB vs mid-market,” or “manufacturing vs construction”—and a suggested ICP profile based on outcomes like retention, expansion, and conversion.
Colton Medina: We’ve tried a few scoring models internally, but they end up being subjective. How do you keep it grounded?

Arjun Mehta: Great question—our approach is outcome-backed. We start with what “good” looks like in your data: renewals, expansion, shorter sales cycles, faster adoption, fewer escalations. Then we map the signals that correlate with those outcomes and weight them accordingly.  
So instead of “someone thinks healthcare is better,” you see: “Healthcare accounts with these characteristics adopt in 14 days, generate 40% fewer support tickets, and renew at a higher rate—so they score higher.” And you can tune the drivers based on what your team believes matters.
Colton Medina: Okay. But we’re not a typical SaaS—our customer signals are a bit messy. Some in CRM, some in support, and some is just notes.

Arjun Mehta: Totally normal. We’re designed for that reality. We can ingest structured and semi-structured data: CRM fields, onboarding surveys, product usage if you have it, support tickets, and yes—interview notes or call notes. Even if notes aren’t perfect, they help enrich the “why” behind segments.  
For a quick initial model, many teams start with CRM + support + a handful of “known good customers,” then iterate once the first cut of the fit score exposes patterns.
Colton Medina: And what do we actually do with it? Like, say we get a fit score. How does that help product planning?

Arjun Mehta: One of the most common use cases is product planning: identifying high-fit customers with unmet needs to guide roadmap bets.  
Practically, you’d look at your top-fit segment and ask: “Where are they getting stuck? What do they request? What causes support burden?” Customer_Analyzer surfaces those patterns so product can prioritize work that helps the customers most likely to succeed and expand.  
At the same time, it can flag segments that look attractive in pipeline but have low fit—maybe they churn more, take longer to onboard, or have higher support load—so you avoid building for the wrong audience.
Colton Medina: That resonates. We’ve definitely shipped things that ended up being “nice to have” for a segment that never stuck around.

Arjun Mehta: Exactly—and that’s where the driver breakdown is useful. If a segment is low-fit, it’ll tell you whether it’s because of time-to-value, adoption, support burden, or something else. Then product and go-to-market can align on whether to fix it, deprioritize it, or change the way you position to it.
Colton Medina: Speaking of positioning—how does the messaging part work? We struggle to explain the value consistently.

Arjun Mehta: The second core output is positioning recommendations. Once the system understands which segments are highest fit and why, it generates practical messaging: value propositions, differentiators, proof points, and common objections with suggested responses—tailored to those segments.  
So if the data shows your best customers consistently cite a certain pain, and they adopt quickly when a specific workflow is highlighted, it pushes that to the front of your narrative. It also helps sales avoid chasing low-fit deals where objections repeat and cycles drag.
Colton Medina: Got it. I’m curious how much lift this is. We don’t have a lot of bandwidth for a long implementation.

Arjun Mehta: Totally fair. For the first phase, we aim for “useful in weeks, not quarters.” Typically we start with a lightweight data connection to your CRM and support system, and you pick 6–10 fit drivers you care about. We produce an initial fit model, review it with you, and refine.  
The key deliverable early is: a ranked view of segments/accounts, what’s driving fit, and a draft ICP that product and GTM can react to.
Colton Medina: Who usually owns this internally? Product ops? Rev ops?

Arjun Mehta: Usually a partnership. For product planning, product ops or product leadership often sponsors it, and rev ops helps with CRM and data hygiene. But we keep the initial scope small so it doesn’t become a cross-functional science project.
Colton Medina: Makes sense. What would you need from us to show something concrete?

Arjun Mehta: For a solid first pass: access to your CRM fields for accounts and opportunities, basic outcome tags like won/lost and renewal/expansion if available, and a feed of support tickets or categories. If you have onboarding survey responses, even better.  
Then we’d do a working session to define your initial fit drivers—things like “time-to-value” proxies, adoption indicators, and support load—based on how Zephyrroot defines a successful customer.
Colton Medina: And then you can compare segments? Like we argue about enterprise vs mid-market a lot.

Arjun Mehta: Yes—segment comparisons are built-in. We can look at enterprise vs mid-market and show: differences in fit score, which drivers are helping or hurting, and how that ties to outcomes. It’s a good way to settle debates with evidence rather than opinions.
Colton Medina: This is interesting. I’m not going to commit on the spot, but I’d be open to a deeper look. What’s the next step?

Arjun Mehta: Great—next step is a full 30–45 minute discovery where we map your current segments, define what “good customer” means at Zephyrroot, and identify the best initial data sources. If it’s helpful, I can also show a sample fit score dashboard and a driver breakdown so you can see how it looks in practice.  
Do you prefer early next week or later in the week?
Colton Medina: Early next week works. Tuesday morning?

Arjun Mehta: Tuesday morning is great. How about 10:30 AM your time? I’ll send a calendar invite. Before that call, I’ll include a short checklist of the CRM fields and support data that are most useful, so you can tell me what’s realistic. Sound good?
Colton Medina: Yep, send it over. I’ll loop in our RevOps lead as well.
Arjun Mehta: Perfect. I’ll send the invite and the checklist right after this. Thanks, Colton—talk Tuesday.
Colton Medina: Thanks, Arjun. Talk then.
